Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Compact Ultra High Resolution 360 Degree Imaging System
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will advance the state of the art in compact 360-degree camera systems, achieving sizes of about 1/8 of current systems, without compromising the quality or resolution of the optics. Convex mirror based optics has resulted in the realization of very high-resolution ultra-wide angle camera systems. A fundamental limitation in these systems has been the size of the optics in relation to the size of the imaging sensor. Mirror diameters in the range of 10 times the size of the sensor have been achieved. The objective of this research is to overcome the above limitation and achieve mirror diameters at the level of 3-5 times the size of the sensor, keeping ultra high resolution across the entire field of view. In this Phase II project, a miniature high-resolution 360-degree prototype system including optics and camera sensor will be built to demonstrate this capability.

The broader impact of this project will be will to increase the market reach of ultra-wide angle cameras for multiple applications, including video-conferencing, robotics and home surveillance. This new approach to designing optics will result in substantially reducing the form factor of high-resolution wide-angle optics. The high-resolution camera sensors available in the consumer market today can be better used in very small ultra-wide angle video cameras with the ability for multiple remote users to decide where they want to look independent of each other. This has the potential of transforming the market for pan-tilt-zoom cameras to "solid-state pan/tilt/zoom" cameras. The very low size, weight and power cameras that would result from this research can result in small wireless, battery powered systems that would increase the proliferation of cameras for a variety of different applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
High resolution ultra-wide angle (360 degree) optics are becoming increasingly important in a number of applications ranging from military vehicles to consumer videoconferencing solutions. The use of convex conic mirror based optics has resulted in the realization of very high resolution ultra-wide angle camera systems, with pixel resolutions of up to 100 Megapixels for ultra-wide angle video systems and up to Gigapixel resolution for scanning systems. The use of single view point parabolic and hyperbolic mirrors provide additional benefits such as minimizing optical aberrations and providing the basis of pure geometrical transformations for low power image processing. A fundamental limitation in these systems has been the size of the optics in relation to the size of the imaging sensor.

The objective of this research is to advance the state of the art in compact 360 degree optics with a goal of achieving small mirror diameters, keeping ultra-high resolution across the entire field of view. In the Phase II effort, a prototype compact form factor 360-degree panoramic optic was designed and built. A camera platform leveraging GPU based processing for real time high resolution panoramic video was built and demonstrated. The reduction in size to 1/8th of the original size of mirror based panoramic imaging optics, preserving high resolution with low light performance has opened up multiple commercial and consumer applications for the technology, in addition to defense and homeland security applications.

Contributions within Discipline:

In this project, we have identified and demonstrated the design and fabrications approaches and techniques necessary to advance the state of the art in ultra wide angle mirror based optical system to achieve significant improvements in size and scale relative to the current state of the art. We believe that development of products based on this concept will lead to a significant increase in the adoption of high resolution ultra wide angle video camera systems as this approach helps in eliminating one of key customer compromises in these systems.

 

Contributions Beyond Science and Engineering:

The products developed using this significant advance in our design approach will expand the available market for ultra wide angle cameras. Small optics that cover a 360 degree field of view are unobtrusive and can be used for a variety of different commercial and defense applications. RemoteReality has incorporated this design approach in all of its optical platforms used for applications such as video conferencing, smart home cameras, home surveillance and cameras for autonomous vehicles using this approach. RemoteReality's BlueJay360 camera platform is the first commercial product to be launched in 2018 using this technology.
